title: 114_hr6240
content: The "Climate Solutions Commission Act of 2016" acknowledges the increase in extreme weather events and the negative impacts of climate change. Efforts to reduce climate risk are crucial to protect the economy, infrastructure, and public safety. There is bipartisan support for reducing greenhouse gas emissions through viable policies. The "National Climate Solutions Commission" is established to review and recommend actions to reduce greenhouse gas emissions in the US based on scientific findings to avoid climate consequences. The National Climate Solutions Commission will consist of 10 members appointed within 3 months of the Act's enactment. Members will be appointed by the President, Senate and House leaders, Majority and Minority Leaders of the Senate, and Speaker and Minority Leader of the House of Representatives. The National Climate Solutions Commission, comprised of 10 members appointed by various government leaders, must convene within 6 months of the Act's enactment. The Commission is tasked with providing recommendations within 18 months, with eligible members coming from academic, scientific, or industry organizations related to the economy, energy, climate, or public health. The National Climate Solutions Commission, comprised of 10 members appointed by government leaders, focuses on energy exploration, solid waste, transportation, chemical manufacturing, agriculture, construction, and forestry. Ineligible members are those affiliated with entities that have contributed to the Commission. The National Climate Solutions Commission, with 10 appointed members, covers various sectors like energy, transportation, and agriculture. No additional funds can be used for Commission activities. The Secretary of the Treasury can collect private sector donations for the Commission. Transparency is required for all donations and spending, to be publicly available online. Additionally, a Government Accountability Office study and report are mandated. The Comptroller General will conduct a study on energy efficiency and renewable energy loan programs, Green Banks, and financial tools focused on reducing greenhouse gas emissions. A report with study results and assessments of successful financial tools will be submitted to Congress within 180 days. Institutions successful in reducing greenhouse gas emissions while maintaining economic growth and employment will be studied by the Comptroller General.
